docs.title: About Us
docs.text:
Berkeley CSF's budget analysts act as student consultants to campus units that receive student registration fees. We also serve as student representatives on committees that manage referenda fee funding. At the end of the academic year, CSF members conduct interviews with employees and leaders of campus organizations, and formulate budget reports based on their findings.

Jaysa Garcia Chair Jaysa is a senior majoring in Computer Science & English. When she's not working for CSF, she volunteers as a staff member at the OCF and plays video games on her steam deck. She likes experimenting with different distributions of Linux and learning about free and open-source software. She decided to join CSF to represent the student interests when it comes to student fees and ensure those fees are used for projects which benefit the UC Berkeley community. Brinda Garg External Vice Chair Brinda is a junior studying Material Science and Engineering with a minor in Data Science. She hopes to pursue a career at the intersection of engineering and finance. During her free time, she enjoys exploring the bay, reading, and spending time with friends. She joined CSF to learn more about the impact of students tuition and provide student input on the usage of SSF funds. Stefania Lord Internal Vice Chair Stefania is a junior majoring in Environmental Economics and Policy. She’s passionate about making an impact and plans to pursue a career in sustainable business. In her free time she enjoys spending time in nature, exploring, being active, and drinking matcha. Stefania joined CSF to serve as a voice for the student body and to ensure efficient allocation of resources that benefit the UC Berkeley community. Rodrigo Lopez Rodrigo is a junior studying Data Science. Passionate about education and storytelling, he co-founded UC Berkeley's first Salvadoran-centered DeCal. Through CSF, he aims to examine the narratives of how student funds are allocated and collaborate with campus communities to develop data-driven solutions that increase awareness of student resources. In his free time, he enjoys dancing and all things running, from marathons to sweet treat runs. Maeve Klement Maeve is a sophomore majoring in Economics and minoring in History and Public Policy. In her free time, she enjoys running, playing tennis, baking, and board games. She joined CSF to be an advocate for student needs, ensuring that student fees are spent in ways that support the personal, academic, and career goals of all students. She was also interested in learning about how student fees are allocated to different groups on campus and what resources they provide for students. Nayan joined CSF to better understand how Berkeley's funds are being used and how we can change that to improve students' experiences. Manal Ali Manal is a sophomore studying Data Science and Public Health. She enjoys visiting coffee shops, hiking, and spending time with friends. She's passionate about improving quality of life, and is particularly interested in the intersection of quantitative analysis and social justice. Manal joined CSF to ensure that funding is allocated in a way that best serves UC Berkeley students. Saksham Jain Saksham is a sophomore majoring in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS). He enjoys working on passion projects, attending entrepreneurial events in the Bay Area, and watching founder podcasts. In his free time, he likes playing volleyball, discussing philosophy, and hiking. docs.title: Cost of Attendance
docs.text:
“Core fee” is an umbrella term that encompasses tuition, non-resident supplemental tuition, professional degree supplemental tuition, self-supporting graduate professional degree (night classes), and the SSF.

Core fees are paid by all relevant student groups as a requirement for attendance at the University. They also fund “core” university functions (such as lecturer salary, janitorial services, classroom space, wifi, etc.) which are necessary to the academic experience.

Note that these charts depict fees per quarter for the academic year 2025-26. Additional fees that are not included in these charts can be found in the Additional Fees section.

docs.title: The Cohort Model
docs.text:
The Tuition Stability Plan was implemented in 2021 and introduced the cohort model of tuition and fees. A student's cohort is determined by the year that they initially enrolled at UC Berkeley. Under the cohort model, the amount each student pays in Tuition, the Student Services Fee, and Nonresident Supplemental Tuition (if applicable) is locked as the amount that they paid during their first year enrolled, and will not increase.

Note that the Tuition Stability plan only applies to those three charges, and not other fees such as the Berkeley Campus Fee or Transit Fee.

Source: UC Office of the President - Cohort Implementation Guidelines

The entire Berkeley Campus Fee is comprised of smaller campus-based fees. Each of these was voted on and approved by the UC Berkeley student body during a past election cycle.

  • Lower Sproul Fee

    Although it once went toward the construction of MLK and Eschleman Student Union, this fee now pays for some of the maintenance of those buildings.

    Learn More

  • Wellness Fee

    This fee goes toward RecSports, the University Health Center, and PATH2CARE. The discretionary portion of the fee funds other student organizations and campus departments each year.

    Learn More

  • Health Fee

    This covers the salaries and benefits of multiple staff positions at the University Health Center, and a few other services there.

    Learn More

  • Big C Fee

    This fee funds the Centers for Educational Justice and Community Engagement (EJCE). It also funds student organization projects that target underserved campus populations each year.

    Learn More

  • Life Safety Fee

    The Life Safety fee funds projects that keep the architecture of campus spaces safe for students, such as building renovations and seismic retrofitting.

    Learn More

  • Basic Needs Fee

    This fee goes toward the Basic Needs department under the Divison of Equity and Inclusion. It funds services related to food, housing, and financial security for students in need.

    Learn More

  • GOLD Fee

    The GOLD Fee funds the Centers for Educational Equity and Excellence (CE3), which supports the success of non-traditional students at Berkeley. CE3 houses programs such as the Educational Opportunity Program (EOP), Transfer Student Center (TSC), and Student Parent Center (SPC).

    Learn More

  • TGIF Fee

    TGIF goes toward the Student Environmental Resource Center. The fee also supports the Green Initiative Fund, which distributes grants to projects that promote sustainability on campus.

    Learn More

  • V.O.I.C.E. Fee

    This fee supports the DailyCal, UC Berkeley's student-run newspaper.

    Learn More

  • Student Center Fee

    Once funding renovations to the Dining Commons in the Student Union Complex, the Student Center Fee now pays for some of the maintenace and operations of MLK and Eschleman.

    Learn More

  • Housing Security Fee

    This fee goes towards the Housing Security Award Fund, which students can qualify for by applying to the Basic Needs Center's Emergency Fund.

    Learn More

  • Ethnic Studies Fee

    This fee goes towards the Ethnic Studies Department at UC Berkeley. Specifically, it funds the Ethnic Studies' 5th account, which distributes grants to student-initiated events for the Ethnic Studies Community.

    Learn More

  • ASUC Fee (Undergrad Students Only)

    The ASUC Fee goes toward the undergraduate student government's internal budget, which includes senator stipends and ASUC chartered programs, as well as registered student organizations that apply through the ABSA application.

    Learn More

  • GA Fee (Grad Students Only)

    The GA Fee goes toward the graduate student government's internal budget, as well as registered graduate student organizations.

    Learn More

  • STARR Fee (Undergrad Students Only)

    The STARR fee funds multiple programs, student, and full-time staff positions within the bridges Multicultural Resource Center on campus, which provides services related to recruitment and retention of first-generation low-income students of color.

    Learn More

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
The Associated Students of the University of California (ASUC), is the officially recognized student association at the University of California, Berkeley. Known as one of the largest and most autonomous student organizations in the nation, the ASUC is an independent 501(c)3 non profit organization separate from University governance.

In addition to controlling funding for student clubs and organizations, providing resources and student programming, overseeing commercial activities and student services including the Cal Student Store and Lower Sproul Plaza in partnership with the ASUC Student Union, the ASUC advocates for students on a university, local, state, and national level and represents the student body on administrative campus committees.

ASUC Meetings are 1.5 hours long and are typically held every Wednesday in 412 Eshleman Hall in the Fall and Spring.

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
The fee was originally established in 2005 by a student referendum vote to provide several key health services demanded by students at that time. Without the Health fee, implementing these would have resulted in more increased out-of-pocket costs for students: in particular, co-pays for primary and urgent care and SHIP premiums.

Breakdown of the Health Fee when it was first implemented

Many of these programs receive funding from HFAB to this day; however, the referendum emphasizes that health fee allocations should shift based on student demand. Services that might have been crucial for students five years ago may be less so now, while the need for a different program rapidly increased. The fee level may also need to be increased, or decreased, to match the needs of the current students who pay it.

Source: Berkeley Student Affairs: Health Fee Final Ballot 2005

docs.title: The Health Fee Advisory Board
docs.text:
To ensure these annual changes get made, the referendum established the Health Fee Advisory Board. HFAB is an oversight committee which works to ensure that the Health Fee dollars are spent effectively at the Tang Center. We meet in the Fall to set priorities for Health Fee spending and recommend fee levels for the upcoming academic year. Recently, HFAB members have fought for initiatives to improve mental health support for BIPOC students and hired additional nurse practitioners, medical assistants, and counselors to ensure students receive the services they need.

Current Health Fee Funded Services

  • Primary Care
  • Urgent Care + Lab, Radiology and Pharmacy to align with extended hours
  • Mental Health Services
    • Counseling and Psychological Services
    • Psychiatry
    • Social Services
  • Preventative Services
    • Health Promotion
  • Ease of Use
    • Information technology (e.g., eTang patient portal)
    • Appointment making

Keep in mind that the Campus Health Care Fee is intended to “supplement but not supplant” the other sources of income for UHS (tuition, SHIP premiums, etc). Our objective is to keep the fee level as low as possible while still meeting student health needs.

docs.title: Membership
docs.text:
The voting members of the Health Fee Advisory Board are student representatives from the following groups:

  1. ASUC (2-3 Members)
  2. Graduate Assembly (GA) (2-3 Members)
  3. Committee on Student Fees (CSF) (2-3 Members)
  4. Student Health Advisory Committee (SHAC) (1-2 Members)
  5. At large members from the Berkeley student community

HFAB also welcomes any UC Berkeley student who would like to represent student interests at the Tang Center! Contact hfab@berkeley.edu to get involved.

HFAB also has two University Health Services (UHS) staff that help the committee operate.

Name Position Email Bené Gatzert UHS, Chief Strategy Officer bene@berkeley.edu Cory Vu UHS, Associate Vice Chancellor coryvu@berkeley.edu

Two students are also selected from the board each year to serve as co-chairs of the committee. They work with Bené to handle the logistics and planning necessary for HFAB to run smoothly.

Name Email Stefania Lord sllord615@berkeley.edu Jaysa Garcia jaysagarcia@berkeley.edu

If you have questions or concerns regarding HFAB and the Health Fee, reach out to hfab@berkeley.edu and one of these members will get back to you.

docs.title: Responsibilities
docs.text:
The two primary purposes of HFAB are outlined in the fee referendum:

  1. Recommend changes in the allocation of fee revenues to meet the evolving health needs of Berkeley students
  2. Advise on adjustments to the fee level

HFAB members go out of their way to talk to other students about what services they utilize or want to see from the Tang Center. Since the decisions HFAB makes affect the entire campus population, getting additional input from the Berkeley community is crucial to ensuring that HFAB represents their interests.

In order to make informed decisions, HFAB interviews staff from different units of the Tang Center each week in the Fall. These meetings give the board an idea of how current HFAB allocations are being spent, the success of individual programs, and what projects might be appropriate for the Health Fee to fund in the future.

docs.title: Fee Recommendations
docs.text:
At the end of the Fall semester, HFAB members write a recommendation to the Associate Vice Chancellor of Health and Well-being (AVC) on the Health Fee level for the upcoming academic year. It addresses any concerns the committee may have with Tang Center services, and recommends UHS projects for the coming year. Historically, the AVC always follows HFAB's fee level recommendation.

Fee Level Cap

The health fee increase cannot exceed healthcare inflation rates for physician and clinical services published by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics for that year.

All past HFAB recommendations and reports are available at uhs.berkeley.edu/hfab.
